Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter had excellent communication skills and this came in handy in explaining assignment requirements.He also took time to help students, often scheduling time outside of regular TA hours to help answer any additional questions
Instructor: Peter Berrill  he was very responsive and knowledgeable on the topic
Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter Berrill
Instructor: Peter Berrill  He was very helpful.
Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter Berrill

Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter was fantastic! He knew the material very well and was able to explain concepts in depth and from different angles. He was also exceptionally patient in working with me one on one when I was not grasping the material.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter had excellent communication skills and this came in handy in explaining assignment requirements.He also took time to help students, often scheduling time outside of regular TA hours to help answer any additional questions
Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter was good at working through problems with me, but I got the sense that Edgar hadn't briefed him much before the rest of the class.

Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter was a fantastic TF! He was patient and has a strong grasp of the material, and was able to clearly explain the concepts and answer questions. He was a huge help with problem sets and the final project. I would have appreciated receiving more frequent feedback on problem sets.

Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter was an excellent teaching assistant! He was approachable, willing to help with anything I needed, and helped explain concepts that I was not able to understand from the lectures. He also was an incredible asset for the problem sets.

Instructor: Peter Berrill  Peter was a good TA. He was good at explaining the material and was very patient. And He was very helpful during office hours but he can definitely improve on email responses and being more available to make appointments.

Instructor: Peter Berrill  He was excellent at explaining concepts covered in class during the office hours, he was always willing to meet to help with assignments and project work and he was patient with topics that I struggled to understand. He greatly helped me out with my final project data recovery, I could have not done it without him!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class started off too difficult, and then didn't progress in difficulty. I think instead Edgar needs to begin the first couple of weeks with really really basic examples, like perhaps we do the first problem set in excel so people can see what matrices look like during linear algebra transformations. Then after a couple weeks of simple stuff, when the whole class is on the same page, then we can accelerate more quickly into asking more complicated questions and answering them using IOA.

The readings were dense and would have been difficult to digest before the class lecture discussion. In addition, the problem sets were too frequent and did not allow for adequate feedback between problem sets. Edgar Hertwich is brilliant and knows the material, but could improve his communication skills and spend more time explaining the concepts.

I think this course is so valuable to the F&ES curriculum, but I think it needs some restructuring. The course should keep one lecture and one lab section - this was so valuable to learning MatLab. I think there needs to be a session on learning linear algebra and matrix multiplication and the math behind the work required for the course. I also think there needs to be more explanation of what we are doing in MatLab and what it means. It felt like we were just supposed to figure this stuff out on our own outside of class and come into class and already know it - when most of us had never see MatLab before nor done any linear algebra.
Somewhat confusing course.
Edgar is extremely knowledgeable but can sometimes move through material very quickly that not all students have grasped.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: 1. Exposure to technical carbon modeling skills that helped build meaningful bridges between the theoretical aspects of climate and carbon to the quantitative. 2. The applied math course at FES was very theoretical, in contrast with this course that covers - in part - similar content ie matrices and actually helps one build meaningful intuition in working with these values. 3. The course helps one develop the ability to easily work with large meta-data sets
Learning Matlab, and gaining insight into tiers of production.
Understanding the input-output process of calculating carbon footprints is valuable, and learning how to use Matlab was a great skill.
I loved that there was a lab component to this course - I feel like I learned a hard skill and a new software, which I was looking for.
The data files provided was very nice.
The final project was the most useful and interesting aspect of the course.

Relevance- it is critical that we have a course that will allow students to understand concepts or methods of quantification within the climate change discourse on a deeper level. I really valued having the opportunity to take a deep dive into what carbon footprint modeling really tells us and how it can be used or misused in climate mitigation strategies. It is critical that we have this level of depth at FES.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: This course is very helpful for those students keen on climate at FES and is useful in addition to the policy classes on climate and carbon. However, because it was a new course, I think it took a bit of time for us to build a certain level of intuition but once we were able to, the remaining classes were very enjoyable. I think that, while some classes such as the Applied Math class can be to a certain extent theoretical, they can, given the right TA support, be useful in just helping with understanding basic matrix operations as this is what the first portion of this class addresses. However, this course can still achieve this if it is allotted a module training session outside of the allotted class time.

Lecture classes needed more variety. I suggest that sometimes the class splits up and prepares two different journal articles that we then debate in class. Or one week instead of a problem set the readings require a written response that we discuss in class.
Explain the concepts and processes in more detail and with more clarity. Spend additional time covering linear algebra at the beginning of class so everyone is on the same page.

Better explaining/showing/teaching the fundamentals of the industrial ecology analysis we did in class. We need to really learn what the different matrices represent, how they are added/multiplied, and how to write the code in order to get the answer you are looking for. We had a few quizzes in class and after the first quiz some students did not perform well. Instead of giving us an answer key and giving us a session to learn what was done wrong, we were just given the quiz again. This did not allow for maximum learning and understanding of the content.

Making linear algebra course as a prerequisite would have been good because we had to waste the first few classes going over basic matrices. And some people were still confused on simple matrices calculations... If we could use those class times on actual carbon footprinting calculations not linear algebra, I would have been able to learn more.
The classes could benefit from some student engagement or discussion time to break up the class time between teaching and student led discussion.
Course requirements would be helpful- this course was a bit above my level.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I think the course and lab lectures complemented each other very well.

Not very much of a relationship. The lectures were very theoretical and the lab sessions were extremely practical. Now that I'm done with the class, I've learned the practical part because I had to practice it every week, but the theory side isn't quite so reinforced.

The sessions in the computer lab were valuable, particularly when we were able to work through the code for problem sets. However, the lab sections need to be thought through and explained more clearly before class.
The lectures and the labs did not always relate, but that was not a big flaw with this course.
Yes, the lab sections were very helpful.
Yes, what was taught in a lecture was then applied in a lab session and Matlab modelling

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: One of my goals coming into F&ES was to build better understanding of both the policy and technical aspects of climate. While classes on the latter at F&ES were few and far between, I was certainly gained a lot from Climate & Society taught in the spring and Carbon Modelling by Hertwich.
This fits well with the Industrial Ecology program, and I have a better understanding of how carbon footprints are calculated.

I hope this course continues to be taught at F&ES because I think it teaches a really valuable and emerging skill set. That said, I think the course and method of teaching needs some review and changes.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to better understand large climate and carbon data sets and how one might use these data sets to provide quantitative, empirical answers for critical policy questions on climate and carbon.
I wanted to learn modeling skills
I wanted to gain carbon footprint modeling knowledge and improve my quantitative skills.
This course aligns very well with my future career goals. I also wanted to learn a hard skill and a new software.
Wanted to learn MatLab and wanted to learn carbon footprint calculations and input-output tables.
I wanted to learn more about product and sector carbon footprint analysis, this is something that is integral to many business challenges and I find this to be useful in my future career.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
I gained a lot from this class, but would have gained more skills/knowledge with clearer instruction.
Yes it did
I expected to walk away with a deeper understanding of what was learned than I did.
Some of the materials could have been explained more clearly.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A. No group work
I talked through some of the problem sets with other students in the class, which was helpful.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Highly recommended for students who want to better understand large climate and carbon data sets and how one might use these data sets to provide quantitative, empirical answers for critical policy questions on climate and carbon. Elementary knowledge of matrix operations is important Incredibly helpful for those students who are keen on specializing in climate and energy at FES, in addition to the policy classes. It is also a great complement to the Energy Systems Analysis class offered in the fall as well as Climate and Society offered in the spring.
This is a challenging class, and the instruction is inconsistent. Wait another year while they work out the kinks before taking it.
Be sure to ask questions in class if the material does not make sense, and practice working through Matlab code early in the semester to help with problem sets and the final project.

You will have to do a lot of the learning on your own time (about linear algebra, matrix multiplication, input-output tables) as this is not well explained in class. If you are comfortable doing this, then you should definitely take this class as you will learn a great hard skill!
Please take a linear algebra class..
Make sure you are able to handle the material and have adequate room built into your schedule if you will need more time to work with the problem sets.
